thread.title: Vellum use for Parliamentary records and bills
thread.title_full: Vellum use for Parliamentary records and bills - BBC News

author: BBC
title: Vellum use for Parliamentary records and bills
text:
Media playback is unsupported on your device Vellum use for Parliamentary records and bills 26 October 2015 Last updated at 14:24 GMT
An annual saving of Â£80,000 could be made in Parliament by using paper instead of vellum for formally recording Acts of Parliament, a committee of MPs has said.
But calligrapher Patricia Lovett said the Domesday Book and Magna Carta have only endured physically because they'd been made up - at least partly - of long-lasting vellum, which is itself made from calfskin.
She spoke to Jo Coburn, Tory MP Paul Scully, and Labour MP Anna Turley about the bid to keep using vellum.
More clips from the Daily and Sunday Politics
